title: Labor defends backdown on 'big stick' laws
text:
Labor is defending its backdown on the coalition's "big stick" energy laws, which will allow the federal government to intervene much more directly in the market.

The laws will make it easier to break up the assets of energy companies that abuse their market power.

In the last term of parliament, the opposition characterised the proposed laws as a "bizarre, Venezuelan-style intervention" that would chill investment.

"The bill is a very different bill to the one that was initially presented by the government in two major respects," Labor frontbencher Mark Butler told ABC radio on Wednesday.

Mr Butler said the legislation had been amended to give the competition watchdog and Federal Court - rather than the minister - greater discretion to intervene in the market.

He said a possible "back door" to privatising energy assets had also been narrowed.

"We think we have knocked off the worst elements of this legislation, particularly around the possible privatisation of publicly-owned assets," Mr Butler said.

Labor will move an amendment to prevent the laws being used to advance privatisations.

"If those amendments are not supported by the government then we will vote against the bill," Mr Butler said.

The changes were made to legislation last December, but Labor only changed its position this week.

Mr Butler said businesses had changed their attitude towards the proposed laws.

But the Australian Industry Group, which represents big businesses, has warned the "disproportionate" intervention powers will end up hurting energy customers.

In a submission to a Senate committee investigating the bill, Ai Group chief executive Innes Willox said the measures outlined in the bill could hurt the existing operations of energy companies and stymie investments.

"More generally, creating a power to break up energy businesses would set a poor precedent for disproportionate government intervention in the wider economy," Mr Willox said.

"It would raise deep reservations among domestic and international institutional investors regarding investment in Australia, including in the infrastructure sector."

The peak industry body also warned ongoing uncertainty over national energy and climate policy had exacerbated nerves in a market undergoing fundamental changes to technology and business models.

"Investment to remedy these problems will be lower and slower than it should be if this bill is passed," Mr Willox said.
